content.title: Splenic Artery Aneurysm
content.definition: Focal dilation of the splenic artery to greater than 1.5 times normal diameter (typically >1 cm), representing the most common visceral artery aneurysm (60% of all VAAs) and third most common intra-abdominal aneurysm after aortic and iliac aneurysms.

key_concepts.description: Female predominance (4:1 F:M ratio), incidence 0.1-2% in general population, mean age 52 years, higher prevalence in multiparous women and portal hypertension patients

Multifactorial including medial fibrodysplasia, portal hypertension (increased splenic blood flow), multiparity (hormonal effects on vessel wall), atherosclerosis, pancreatitis (pseudoaneurysm), and connective tissue disorders
True SAA involves all vessel wall layers, typically calcified and fusiform; pseudoaneurysm results from pancreatitis or trauma, lacks true wall, higher rupture risk
Overall rupture risk 2-10%, increased with size >2cm, pseudoaneurysm type, pregnancy (25% rupture rate with 75% maternal and 95% fetal mortality), and portal hypertension

95% asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging; symptomatic patients present with left upper quadrant or epigastric pain; rupture causes sudden severe pain, hypotension, double rupture phenomenon into lesser sac

Initial contained rupture into lesser sac with temporary hemodynamic stability, followed by rupture through foramen of Winslow into peritoneal cavity with sudden decompensation - pathognomonic of splenic artery aneurysm rupture
CT angiography is gold standard showing calcified wall (signet ring sign), contrast enhancement; ultrasound may show anechoic structure with Doppler flow; angiography for treatment planning
Symptomatic aneurysms, diameter >2cm, pregnancy or childbearing potential, liver transplant candidates, rapid growth (>0.5cm/year), pseudoaneurysms regardless of size
Endovascular (coil embolization, stent graft) preferred for proximal/mid splenic aneurysms; surgical options include aneurysmectomy, ligation with splenectomy, or exclusion with splenic preservation
Short gastric and gastroepiploic collaterals can maintain splenic perfusion after proximal ligation; distal SAA near hilum may require splenectomy

signs: Kehr sign (left shoulder pain from diaphragmatic irritation)

learning_objectives: Identify splenic artery aneurysm as most common visceral aneurysm
Recognize high-risk populations (multiparous women, portal hypertension)
Understand the double rupture phenomenon and its clinical significance
Apply appropriate treatment thresholds (>2cm, pregnancy, symptomatic)
clinical_pearls: Most common visceral artery aneurysm (60% of all VAAs)
4:1 female predominance - think of multiparous women
Pregnancy increases rupture risk to 25% with catastrophic outcomes
Double rupture phenomenon = temporary stability then sudden collapse
Signet ring sign on CT from calcified wall
common_mistakes: Failing to treat all SAAs in women of childbearing potential
Missing pseudoaneurysm in pancreatitis patients (always treat)
Assuming small size is protective (pseudoaneurysms rupture at any size)
Not recognizing liver transplant candidates need treatment
